questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with chronic kidney disease developed secondary hyperparathyroidism for which he was treated appropriately, and was started on cinacalcet. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Cinacalcet is a calcimimetic agent.

It activates the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) in the parathyroids and blocks PTH secretion.

Cinacalcet is a type II calcimimetic agent , it means that it needs either Ca2+ or some other agonist to activate CaSR.

It is indicated for secondary hyperparathyroidism due to chronic kidney disease and tumor of parathyroid gland.

Type I calcimimetic agents are those which can activate CaSR directly such as aminoglycoside and polylysine.

questions.text: A patient on lithium therapy was started on a drug for hypertension. After few days, he developed coarse tremors and other symptoms suggestive of lithium toxicity. Which of the following anti-hypertensive drug is least likely to be the cause of this toxicity?
questions.solution:
Except for nifedipine, all the other drugs (Enalapril, thiazide, furosemide) causes lithium toxicity.

Lithium toxicity occurs with concomitant use of 

  1. Thiazide diurertics (chlorthalidone)
  2. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (enalapril)
  3. Angiotensin II receptor blocker (telmisartan)
  4. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (indomethacin)
  5. Tetracyclines (doxycycline)
  6. Loop diuretics (furosemide)

These act by increasing the tubular reabsorption of lithium, resulting in decreased excretion of lithium and thereby increasing the serum lithium levels, causing toxicity.

Lithium toxicity: 

Serum lithium level greater than 1.5 mEq/L are considered toxic. Acute intoxication is characterized by vomiting, profuse diarrhea, coarse tremor, ataxia, dysarthria, and convulsions. It may progress to cardiac arrhythmias, coma, and death.

Treatment is supportive which includes dialysis, continuous cardiac monitoring, intubation if needed.

Adverse effects of Lithium:

Central nervous system: Lithium at therapeutic levels cause fine tremors and at toxic levels cause coarse tremors. Incoordination, ataxia, and slurred speech can occur at peak serum concentrations.

Lithium enters into the distal tubular cells in kidney via luminal ENaC. However, it accumulates in the distal tubular cells due to the inability of Na+K+ATPase to secrete lithium via basal membrane. Thereby, lithium inhibits GSK-3ß, leading to vasopressin insensitivity, downregulation of aquaporin-2 channels, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Patients present with polyuria and polydipsia. Amiloride blocks entry of lithium into renal distal tubule ENaCs and is used to treat lithium induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Lithium therapy is associated with hypothyroidism and hypercalcemia related to hyperparathyroidism. Lithium therapy causes significant weight gain.

T wave flattening in ECG occurs in few patients on lithium. At toxic levels, sinus bradycardia, AV block, and cardiac arrhythmias occur. Allergic reactions including dermatitis, folliculitis, and vasculitis can occur with lithium use.

Lithium use in early pregnancy causes Ebstein anomaly in the fetus. Fetal lithium exposure is associated with neonatal goiter, CNS depression, hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), and cardiac murmur.

Due to all these adverse effects, patients on lithium therapy should have routine monitoring of serum electrolytes, serum calcium, thyroid profile, renal function tests, ECG, and serum lithium levels.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

questions.text: Which of the following is true about pegylated-filgrastim?

choices.text: Duration of action is shorter than normal filgrastim
Added advantage is that it can be taken orally
It should not be administered in sickle cell patients
It is not effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia

questions.solution:
Patients with sickle cell anemia should not receive pegylated filgrastim as it can trigger a sickle cell crisis.

Filgrastim is a recombinant human G-CSF (granulocyte colony-stimulating factor). The pegylated forms of filgrastim, pegfilgrastim, and lipefilgrastim, are longer-acting forms. It is administered subcutaneously or by slow intravenous infusion only.

Indications of recombinant G-CSF:   

  • Severe neutropenia after autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation
  • Severe neutropenia after high dose cancer chemotherapy
  • Severe congenital neutropenias
  • Neutropenia of patients with AIDS receiving zidovudine

Filgrastim is the first FDA-approved drug to treat patients with radiation-induced myelosuppression and to increase survival in such patients.

questions.text: An elderly patient is brought to the emergency room in a drowsy state after taking an overdose of his sleeping pills. His medical history includes insomnia for which he was on alprazolam. Which of the following medication will you administer to this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is presenting with benzodiazepine (alprazolam) overdose. Flumazenil is the drug of choice for this patient.

Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site of the GABAA receptor. It antagonizes both the agonist (benzodiazepines) and inverse-agonist (beta-carbolines) of this receptor.

It is primarily indicated for the management of benzodiazepine overdose and the reversal of benzodiazepine anesthesia. 

Other options:

Option A: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used in the management of opioid overdose.

Option C: Naltrexone, another opioid antagonist, is used in the management of alcohol dependence, prevention of relapse in opioid deaddiction after detoxification, and weight management. It might cause liver failure.

Option D: Nalmefene is a pure opioid antagonist with higher potency than naloxone. It is used for the treatment of opioid toxicity and substance abuse.

Related Pearl: Pure opioid antagonists

Naloxone: short-acting opioid antagonist with duration of action of 1-2 hours. Used in opioid overdose and respiratory depression in newborns due to perinatal opioid use.

Naltrexone: long-acting opioid antagonist with effects lasting till 48 hours. Used for prevention of relapse in opioid addiction treatment. It is associated with hepatotoxicity. It does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.

Nalmefene: long-acting opioid antagonist with a half-life of 8-10 hours administered intravenously. Used in opioid overdose like naloxone.

questions.text: A patient presents with an amoebic liver abscess. He does not have any diarrhea or blood in his stool. His only complaint is vague abdominal pain. On examination of stool, cysts of Entamoeba histolytica are present. How would you treat this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with an amoebic liver abscess and cysts in stool needs treatment with metronidazole (or tinidazole) + a luminal amoebicide like paromomycin, diloxanide furoate, or iodoquinone.

As metronidazole is so well absorbed in the gut, the levels may not be therapeutic in the colonic lumen. The drug is also less effective against cysts. Therefore, patients with amoebic colitis or amoebic liver abscess should receive a luminal agent in addition.

Note: Albendazole is an antihelmintic drug, used to treat hydatid cyst, roundworms, hookworm, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following antifungal drugs is matched correctly with its mechanism of action based on the image given below?
questions.solution:
Amphotericin B is an amphipathic molecule and incorporates itself in the cell membrane by actively binding to ergosterol (as shown in the image by 'C'). This results in the formation of amphotericin-induced pores which cause leakage of the intracellular contents ultimately resulting in cell death.

It is a broad-spectrum antifungal that can be used against Candida albicans, Cryptococcus neoformans, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Sporothrix schenckii, Coccidioides immitis, Aspergillus.

Amphotericin B also has antiprotozoal action along with antifungal properties and is effective against Leishmania.

Adverse effects of amphotericin B include:

  • Infusion-related fever and chills
  • Azotemia/nephrotoxicity- all lipid formulations of amphotericin B are less nephrotoxic than conventional amphotericin B
  • Renal tubular acidosis 
  • Renal wasting of potassium and magnesium
  • Hypochromic normocytic anemia- due to decreased erythropoietin production from the kidney.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of Antifungal drugs

questions.text: True statement about teduglutide is :

choices.text: It is recommended for patients with colorectal cancer

questions.solution:
Teduglutide is a GLP-2 analogue.

It has been recently approved for the treatment of short bowel syndrome. Teduglutide binds to enteric neurons and endocrine cells, stimulating the release of a number of hormones such as insulin-like growth factor, this stimulates mucosal epithelial growth and enhances fluid absorption.

The drug has a t1/2 of 1–2 hours and is administered subcutaneously once daily. It can potentially cause bowel cancer, therefore it is not recommended for patients with active malignancies.

Note: GLP-1 analogs are used for the treatment of Type II diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient with early morning stiffness and chronic pain over small joints was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. She has been on drugs for the past few years, without any improvement. Now, it has been decided to start her on biological agents. Which of the following will not be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
IL-17A antagonist is not used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis.

IL-17A antagonists (secukinumab, ixekizumab) can be used in the treatment of moderate to severe plaque or scalp psoriasis.

All the other 3 are biological Disease Modifying Anti-Rheumatoid Drugs (DMARDs) used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. All biological DMARDs downregulate the immune system and can lead to adverse effects like opportunistic infections and the flaring of latent TB.

Other options:

Option B: IL-1 receptor antagonist - anakinra

Option C: IL-6 receptor antagonist - tocilizumab and sarilumab

Option D: TNF α antagonist - adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, etc.,

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with signs of dehydration due to severe vomiting. The intern gave the patient a parenteral medication, following which the patient developed grimacing and abnormal posturing. What could have been the inciting drug for this reaction?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes the adverse effects characteristic of metoclopramide. The most common adverse effects of metoclopramide involve the central nervous system because it crosses the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and blocks the central D2 receptors.

The adverse effects include:

  • Restlessness
  • Drowsiness
  • Insomnia
  • Anxiety
  • Agitation 
  • Extrapyramidal effects - acute reaction with high doses and long-term therapy. (due to central dopamine receptor blockade)
    • Dystonias
    • Akathisia
    • Parkinsonian features
    • Tardive dyskinesia 

Adverse events are more common among the elderly. Long-term use should be avoided unless absolutely necessary.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the surgery department. Your consultant asks you to prescribe a drug for a patient complaining of heartburn. What will you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Omeprazole 20mg OD 30 mins before breakfast can be prescribed inthis patient. Heartburns are most effectively treated with proton-pump inhibitors (PPI) like pantoprazole, omeprazole, and rabeprazole. PPIs should be ideally given 30 minutes before breakfast.

PPIs are prodrugs, when ingested, get absorbed into the systemic circulation. It then diffuses into the parietal cells of the stomach and accumulates in the acidic secretory canaliculi. Acidic pH in the parietal cell canaliculi causes activation of the PPIs. The maximum proton pump (H+ K+ ATPase) activation corresponds to the peak concentration of PPI resulting in maximum efficacy.

Proton pumps are higher in number after a period of fasting. So, PPIs are usually given in the mornings before breakfast. Food hinders the absorption of PPIs and decreases their bioavailability. Therefore, PPIs are given on an empty stomach, 30 mins before taking food.

PPIs are administered orally in enteric-coated or delayed-release capsules/ granules/ pellets/ oral suspension packets to prevent its degradation by the gastric acid.

Common dosage of PPIs:

  • Pantoprazole 40 mg OD
  • Omeprazole 20-40 mg OD
  • Rabeprazole 20 mg OD 

Note: 

Vonoprazan, a potassium-competitive acid blocker, has been recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of peptic acid-related disorders.

questions.text: A patient is given 200mg of a drug and 150 mg of the drug is excreted in 4 hours. If the elimination of the drug follows first-order kinetics, calculate its half-life?
questions.solution:
The half-life of the given drug is 2 hours.

In this case, the drug follows first-order kinetics. So the rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional to the drug concentration. The half-life of the drug remains constant in first-order kinetics. The rate of clearance is also constant.

The amount of drug eliminated and the drug that remains after each half-life is given below.

Half-life Elimination (%) Drug left in the body(%)
First 50  50
Second 75  25
Third 87.5  12.5
Fourth 93.75  6.25

In this case, 200 mg was given initially and 150mg is excreted in 4 hours.

So percentage of drug eliminated in 4 hours = 150/200 x 100 = 75%

75% of the drug is eliminated in 4 hours. It takes 2 half-lives to eliminate 75% of the drug.

Hence 4 hours = 2 half-lives. In first-order kinetics, the half-life is always constant.

Therefore the half-life of the drug = 2 hours.

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

questions.text:
A patient presented with lethargy and muscle cramps. He was diagnosed with SIADH. Which of the following drugs can be administered orally for the management of his condition?

SIADH - Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
questions.solution:
Tolvaptan is a selective oral V2 receptor antagonist that is FDA-approved for and is effective in clinically significant hyponatremia associated with SIADH.

SIADH is a condition where there is an inappropriate release of antidiuretic hormone or arginine vasopressin (AVP) from ectopic production of AVP. This may be from lung cancer and other neoplasms, increased release induced by various diseases, drugs, or exogenous administration of AVP. It is characterized by impaired water excretion leading to hyponatremia with euvolemia or hypervolemia. 

ADH promotes the reabsorption of water and not the solutes resulting in concentrated urine. This is depicted as high urine osmolality.

Patients usually present with hyponatremia with a euvolemic status. If hyponatremia develops acutely, signs and symptoms may include mild headache, confusion, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, coma, and convulsions. Chronic hyponatremia allows cerebral adaptation, and the patients are asymptomatic despite the hyponatremia.

Laboratory findings in SIADH:

  • Hyponatremia: serum Na+<135 mEq/L
  • Urinary loss of Na+ >25 mEq per day or >40 mEq/L 
  • Urinary osmolality is >100 mOsm/kg
  • Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels are low, usually <10 mg/dL
  • Serum K+ and serum bicarbonate are normal

Treatment: Hyponatremia should be corrected gradually. Restriction of the total fluid intake. Sodium levels can be corrected using hypertonic saline. Tolvaptan and conivaptan are vasopressin receptor-2 antagonists that block the action of anti-diuretic hormones. Other drugs which are useful in the management are demeclocycline and fludrocortisone.

Other options:

Options A and D: Terlipressin and desmopressin are not used in the treatment of SIADH. SIADH is a condition of inappropriate ADH secretion. Since excess vasopressin is the cause of SIADH, giving vasopressin analogs as desmopressin would only worsen the condition. 

Option C: Conivaptan is a nonselective V1a receptor/V2 receptor antagonist that is FDA-approved for the treatment of hospitalized patients with euvolemic and hypervolemic hyponatremia. It is available only for intravenous infusion.

questions.text:
Match the following pairs of drugs with their antidotes.
      Drug         Antidote
  1. Heparin 
  2. Dabigatran
  3. Warfarin
  4. Rivaroxaban
  1. Vitamin K
  2. Protamine sulfate 
  3. Idarucizumab
  4. Andexanet alfa
questions.solution:
Option B is correctly matched.

Drug  Antidote
1. Heparin b. Protamine sulfate
2. Dabigatran c. Idarucizumab
3. Warfarin a. Vitamin K
4. Rivaroxaban d. Andexanet alfa


Heparin - Protamine sulfate(1-b) :

Protamine sulfate is indicated for the reversal of heparin overdose. It binds to long heparin molecules with high affinity and neutralizes anticoagulant activity. Therefore, it completely reverses the action of unfractionated heparin but only partially reverses the action of low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH). It has no effect on fondaparinux.

Dabigatran - Idarucizumab (2-c) :

Idarucizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically acts as a reversal agent for dabigatran. It has a 350 times higher affinity for dabigatran than dabigatran for thrombin. Hence, it forms a complex with dabigatran, which is excreted by the kidneys.

Warfarin - Vitamin K (3-a) :

Vitamin K is given orally as well as intravenously to treat warfarin toxicity. It causes the reversal of anticoagulation effects of warfarin by synthesis of vitamin K–dependent coagulation factors (II, VII, IX, X).

Rivaroxaban - Andexanet alfa (4-d) :

Andexanet alfa is a recombinant analog of factor Xa and is used as a reversal agent for oral factor Xa inhibitors like rivaroxaban, edoxaban, and apixaban. It rapidly reverses the action of these drugs and restores thrombin generation. It is given intravenously.

Note:

questions.text: The drug of choice for the management of acute  alcohol withdrawal is?
questions.solution:
Benzodiazepines are the treatment of choice for the management of acute alcohol withdrawal. It is used to prevent the progression from minor withdrawal symptoms to major ones, such as seizures and delirium tremens.

FDA-approved drugs used in the management of alcohol use disorder are:

  • Disulfiram: It inhibits the enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase. It is used as an aversive drug and causes adverse effects when taken with alcohol. Therefore, it should not be administered until the patient has abstained from alcohol for at least 12 hours.
  • Naltrexone: It is a μ-opioid receptor antagonist. It decreased drinking by decreasing the feeling of reward with alcohol or decreasing craving.
  • Acamprosate: It may act by blocking hyperglutamatergic state and decreases craving.
  • Benzodiazepines: They act by increasing the binding of GABA to GABAA receptors. They are the drugs of choice for the management of acute alcohol withdrawal.
  • Fomepizole: It is used in the management of methanol poisoning. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase.

Other drugs that are commonly used  in the management of alcohol use disorder, but not approved by the FDA are:

  • Gabapentin: It blocks voltage-gated calcium channels
  • Varenicline: It is a partial or full agonist at central nicotinic AChR subtypes. It is used to decrease alcohol consumption and smoking cessation.
  • Nalmefene: It is an antagonist of μ- and κ-opioid receptors. It is also used to treat opioid overdose or dependence.
  • Baclofen: It is a GABAB receptor agonist. It acts as a skeletal muscle relaxant and is used in the management of spasticity.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of breathing difficulty, facial swelling, and palpitations following a bee sting. The drug of choice for anaphylaxis is intramuscular adrenaline (0.5ml in 1:1000 dilution). Activation of beta 2 receptors causes bronchodilation. questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drug is not bactericidal?

questions.text: A 2-year-old child diagnosed with bronchial asthma requires bronchodilator therapy. Which of the following device will you prescribe for this child, to avoid oropharyngeal adverse effects?
questions.solution:
The device in image 3 is a spacer device that can be prescribed to decrease the incidence of propellant-mediated oropharyngeal adverse effects.

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug depositing in the oropharynx and increases the proportion of drugs inhaled into the lower airways. Thus, a less amount of the drug gets swallowed and absorbed from the GI tract and limits local side effects. 

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to children who are not able to use a pMDI alone but can also be used by adults for better drug delivery. The image below shows the use of a spacer device with a face mask which is preferred in children younger than 3 years of age.


The various devices used for the delivery of inhalational drugs are:

Pressurized metered-dose inhalers (pMDI) - Drugs are propelled from a canister in the pMDI with the aid of a propellant. These devices are convenient, portable, and can deliver 50–200 doses of a drug.

Image 1 in the question stem shows a pressurized metered-dose inhaler.


Dry powder inhalers - these devices scatter the drug into a fine powder that is dispersed by air turbulence on inhalation. DPIs have been developed to deliver drugs such as insulin, but the dosing is inconsistent. Children below 7 years find it difficult to use a DPI. 

Image 2 in the question stem shows a dry powder inhaler.


Nebulizers: Two types of nebulizer are available -

  • Jet nebulizers that are driven by a stream of gas (air or oxygen)
  • Ultrasonic nebulizers that use a rapidly vibrating piezoelectric crystal and thus do not require a source of compressed gas.

The nebulizers deliver much higher drug doses as compared pMDIs. These are useful in:

  • Treating acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD
  • Extreme airway obstruction (severe COPD)
  • Delivering inhaled drugs to infants and small children who cannot use the other inhalation devices
  • Administering drugs such as antibiotics in relatively high doses

Image 4 in the question stem shows a nebulizer.

questions.text: A patient with chronic myeloid leukemia was switched to nilotinib as he showed only partial response to imatinib therapy. What is the mechanism resulting in the loss of response?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of the development of resistance to imatinib, which is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor. This condition arises due to point mutations in three separate regions of the kinase domain.

The contact points between imatinib and the enzyme become sites of mutations in drug-resistant leukemic cells and hence these mutations prevent tight binding of the drug and lock the enzyme in its open configuration (the configuration in which it has access to the substrate and is enzymatically active).

Mechanisms other than BCR-ABL kinase mutations play a minor role in resistance to imatinib. They include:

  • Amplification of the wild-type kinase gene has been identified in some cases.
  • Overexpression of MDR-gene leading to increased drug efflux transporter has been shown experimentally but not implicated in clinical resistance.

Nilotinib retains inhibitory activity in the presence of most point mutations that confer resistance to imatinib.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of chronic kidney disease and creatinine of 4.1mg/dl,  presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his great toe for the past 3 hours. On examination, his big toe of the right foot is red and tender. Joint aspiration shows no white cells but shows needle-shaped negatively birefringent crystals. What is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient with a swollen, painful big toe and needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals on synovial tap has acute gout. Due to coexisting chronic kidney disease, the drug of choice in him is intra-articular steroids like triamcinolone or methylprednisolone.

The drug of choice is an acute attack of gout is NSAIDs (Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) like indomethacin or the drug colchicine, but they are poorly tolerated and should not be used in elderly patients with chronic kidney disease.

Drugs used in the management of gout can be classified as:

Drugs that relieve inflammation and pain- These drugs are useful in the management of acute attacks of gout. They are:

  • NSAIDs- They mainly exert their antiinflammatory action by inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzyme (COX). This enzyme converts arachidonic acid to prostanoids, thromboxane A2, and other prostaglandins. 
  • Colchicine- It arrests the cell division in G1 by interfering with microtubule and spindle formation. This results in decreased neutrophil recruitment, decreased neutrophil motility, and decreased release of chemotactic factors. 
  • Glucocorticoids- These drugs bind to the nuclear receptors and decrease the transcription of genes for COX-2, inducible NOS (NOS2), inflammatory cytokines, collagenase, etc, that are responsible for inflammation.

Drugs that inhibit urate formation- These drugs inhibit urate formation by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase. Eg. allopurinol and febuxostat

Uricosuric drugs- These drugs increase the excretion of uric acid. Important ones are:

  • Probenecid- it inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid by inhibiting organic acid transporter (OATs), principally URAT-1.
  • Benzbromarone- It increases uric acid secretion by reversibly inhibiting urate–anion exchanger in the proximal tubule
  • Lesinurad- It inhibits the URAT-1 and OAT-4 transporters, thereby reducing renal uric acid reabsorption.

Pegloticase and rasburicase catalyze the enzymatic oxidation of uric acid into allantoin. This product is soluble and inactive.

questions.text: A patient with bronchial asthma was treated with regular inhaled corticosteroids. He is now commenced on theophylline as an add-on therapy. By which of the following mechanism does this drug enhance the effect of corticosteroids?
questions.solution:
Theophylline enhances the effect of corticosteroids by activation of histone deacetylase.

Theophylline activates histone deacetylase-2. The recruitment of histone deacetylase-2 by glucocorticoid receptors (GRs) switches off inflammatory genes. Through this mechanism, theophylline enhances the anti-inflammatory effects of corticosteroids.

Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug used in the management of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Its other mechanisms of action are as follows:

  • Inhibits phosphodiesterase non-selectively, (PDE3, PDE4, and PDE5) thereby, increasing cellular cAMP and cGMP, causing bronchodilation
  • Adenosine causes bronchoconstriction by releasing histamine and leukotrienes. Theophylline antagonizes adenosine receptors causing bronchodilation
  • Increases IL-10 release, which has an anti-inflammatory effect
  • Decreases gene transcription of pro-inflammatory cytokines
  • Promotes apoptosis of granulocytes, reducing the inflammatory load in the airways

Theophylline is mainly metabolized by the enzyme CYP1A2 enzyme. Various drug interactions of theophylline include:

  • Increased clearance (CYP1A2 enzyme induction) by smoking, phenytoin, rifampicin, and phenobarbitone.
  • Decreased clearance (CYP1A2 enzyme inhibition) by erythromycin, cimetidine, ciprofloxacin, oral contraceptives, and allopurinol.

Important side effects of this drug due to PDE4 antagonism are nausea, vomiting, and gastric discomfort, and those due to adenosine A1 receptor antagonism are diuresis, cardiac arrhythmias, and seizures.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, diagnosed with bipolar disorder is under treatment with lithium for the past 2 months. She now presents with excessive thirst and frequent urination and a diagnosis of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus was made. The administration of desmopressin did not increase the specific gravity of urine. Which is the most appropriate treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate treatment for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) is amiloride.

Lithium is a mood stabilizer with a very narrow therapeutic index hence regular determination of serum concentrations is important. Its use is approved by FDA in acute mania and the prevention of recurrences of bipolar illness in adults or adolescents.

Important side effects of lithium are-

  • Fine tremors in therapeutic dose
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Hypothyroidism
  • T wave flattening
  • CNS toxicity manifests as coarse tremors, giddiness, ataxia, motor incoordination, nystagmus, mental confusion, slurred speech, and hyperreflexia.

The development of NDI is related to the accumulation of Li+ in distal tubular cells and subsequent inhibition of GSK-3β, leading to vasopressin insensitivity and downregulation of aquaporin-2 channels. Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks entry of Li+ into collecting duct cells and thus can be used to treat lithium-induced NDI.

Other options:

Option A: Thiazide diuretics may also lead to lithium toxicity. Lithium competes with sodium for reabsorption. Diuresis leads to Na+ loss and compensatory sodium as well as lithium reabsorption from the proximal tubule, leading to toxicity.

Option C: Furosemide is a loop diuretic. It acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle resulting in increased excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride. Thiazide diuretics also lead to lithium toxicity.

Option D: Chlorpropamide is a long-acting oral sulfonylurea preferred for central diabetes insipidus owing to its enhancing action on circulating vasopressin.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient presented with the following finding. Her medical history includes hypertension for which she has been taking regular medications for the past 3 months. Which of the following medication is most likely to be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows pitting pedal edema in a hypertensive patient. Calcium channel blockers (CCBs) like amlodipine are most likely to be associated with peripheral edema.

The frequency of CCB- induced peripheral edema is both drug-specific (i.e more potent drugs like amlodipine will be associated with higher rates of developing edema) and dose-dependent (i.e incidence of edema increases with an increase in drug dosage and chronicity of its usage). It is more common among females.

CCB-induced peripheral edema occurs due to a disproportionate decrease in the arteriolar resistance than in the venous circulation, resulting in increased hydrostatic pressure in the precapillary circulation. This leads to a fluid shift into the interstitial compartment causing edema.

Treatment:

  • Dose reduction.
  • Interclass switching of CCB - switch to non-dihydropyridines like verapamil, and diltiazem.
  • Addition of a venodilator - ACE inhibitor, ARBs, Nitrates.
  • Others - compression stockings, avoiding prolonged upright position.
  • Definitive treatment would be discontinuation of the CCB and switching to another class of antihypertensives.

Other options:

Option A: Common side effects of ACE inhibitors like enalapril include hypotension, hyperkalemia, dry cough, rashes, urticaria, dysgeusia, gastrointestinal upset, headache, and dizziness.

Option B: Telmisartan, an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARBs), causes adverse effects such as hypotension, hyperkalemia, headache, gastrointestinal upset, and dizziness.

Option D: Adverse effects of thiazide diuretics like hydrochlorothiazide are hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hyperglycemia, hyperuricemia, hypercalcemia, rashes, headache, gastrointestinal upset, and dizziness.

questions.text: A first-year resident administers an intramuscular injection to a patient by the Z track technique. What is the advantage of this technique?
questions.solution:
The advantage of the 'Z-track technique' for intramuscular administration is that it prevents skin staining. 

Z-track technique procedure: 

  1. Stretch the skin by pulling it laterally away from the intended point of injection.
  2. Insert the needle into the site at a 90˚ angle, aspirate by pulling back to see if the needle has a penetrated vessel.
  3. If blood is aspirated withdraw the needle, and repeat the procedure at another site with new equipment and medication.
  4. If no blood is aspirated administer the injection.
  5. Wait for 10 seconds and then withdraw the needle, and release the skin allowing the displaced tissue to seal the needle track.

Advantages: 

  • The 'Z-track' prevents leakage of the medication into the subcutaneous tissue and skin staining through the tract to the surface of the skin
  • Pain intensity is also reduced

questions.text:
You are posted as an intern in the medicine ward where your consultant asks you to make a list of all the patients who require strict therapeutic drug monitoring. All the following patients will be included in your list, except ______.
  1. Epileptic patient on phenytoin
  2. Hypertensive patient on long-term thiazide
  3. Bipolar patient on lithium
  4. Parkinsonism patient on levodopa
  5. Diabetic patient on metformin
questions.solution:
Option B is correct. Thiazide, levodopa, and metformin do not require therapeutic drug monitoring. However, phenytoin and lithium will require strict therapeutic drug monitoring because of their narrow therapeutic window.

Therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) is individualizing drug dosage by maintaining plasma or blood drug concentrations within a targeted therapeutic range or window.

Indications for TDM:

  1. Drugs with low safety margins i.e. narrow therapeutic window (e.g. digoxin, anticonvulsants, antiarrhythmics, theophylline, aminoglycosides, lithium, TCAs, immunomodulators)
  2. Drugs with high individual variations (e.g. lithium, antidepressants)
  3. Drugs with potential toxicity used in renal failure patients (e.g. aminoglycosides, vancomycin)
  4. Poisoning
  5. Drug therapy failure (e.g. failure of response to antibiotics)
  6. To check patient compliance (e.g. psycho-pharmacological agents)

TDM is not necessary for

  1. Drugs whose response is easily measured (eg. antihypertensives, anti-diabetic agents, oral anticoagulants, inhalational general anesthesia)
  2. Prodrugs (e.g. levodopa)
  3. Drugs that have long-lasting effects -Hit and run drugs e.g. reserpine, guanethidine, monoamine oxidase inhibitors, omeprazole)
  4. Irreversible action of drugs (eg. organophosphates, phenoxybenzamine)

questions.text: An obese male patient has been recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease and hypertension. He is started on atorvastatin. Which of the following additional medication can be safely prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Atenolol is a beta-blocker and an anti-hypertensive medication that can be safely prescribed along with statins like atorvastatin because atenolol does not have much interaction with statin metabolism.

Statins are hypolipidemic drugs that act by competitively inhibiting the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase. This allows for a compensatory increase in LDL receptors in the liver and thereby increases LDL catabolism. 

They are well tolerated. However, they can cause notable side effects such as myopathy and liver injury. They occur commonly when statins are concurrently given with nicotinic acid, gemfibrozil, or CYP3A4 inhibitors such as:

  • Amiodarone

Thus, the risk of toxicity of statins increases. Concurrent use of gemfibrozil with statins most commonly causes myopathy (rhabdomyolysis). 

Option C: Digoxin used concurrently with a statin can increase the risk of myopathy.

Option D: Nicotinic acid (Niacin) used concurrently with statins can cause myopathy due to inhibition of skeletal muscle cholesterol synthesis.

questions.text: A patient with chronic angina was prescribed a new drug, ranolazine. This drug acts by which of the following mechanism?

choices.text: Inhibit funny currents in SA node

questions.solution:
Ranolazine acts by late sodium current inhibition in the heart. It is used in the prophylaxis of angina.

Late sodium current (INa) facilitates the entry of calcium via the sodium-calcium exchanger. Inhibition of INa, therefore, reduces the intracellular calcium concentration which in turn reduces the diastolic tension and cardiac contractility.

At higher doses, it may also modify the fatty acid oxidation (pFOX inhibitor), which improves the efficiency of cardiac oxygen utilisation but whether this actually occurs at therapeutic doses is still being studied. It also has mild beta-blocking activity.

Ranolazine is the second-line FDA-approved drug for heart failure. Side effects of ranolazine include dizziness, headache, and postural hypotension.

Other options:

Option A: Ivabradine selectively blocks the funny current (If) channel involved in the generation of automaticity in the SA node. It reduces heart rate and thereby oxygen demand. It does not have any effect on cardiac contractility. It is an FDA-approved drug for the treatment of heart failure. It is also used for treating stable angina.

Option C: Fasudil acts by inhibiting smooth muscle Rho kinase and reduces coronary vasospasm.

Option D: Nicorandil acts as an agonist at ATP-sensitive potassium (KATP) channels i.e. potassium channel opener. It decreases afterload and preload of the heart by its vasodilatory properties at both arterioles and venules. It is used for the treatment of stable angina.

Note: Trimetazidine is a pFOX inhibitor that partially inhibits fatty acid oxidation in the myocardium. Thereby, it decreases the oxygen requirement. It is also used as an anti-anginal agent.

  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels

    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand

    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman was diagnosed with focal seizures and was prescribed ezogabine. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ezogabine is a potassium channel opener.

Ezogabine (retigabine) acts by opening neuronal potassium channels. By opening the K+ channels, it stabilizes the resting membrane potential and reduces the excitability of the nerve membrane.

It is used as an adjunctive treatment for focal seizures.

Serious side effects associated with long-term therapy include retinal abnormalities causing visual defects, skin discoloration, QT prolongation, and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Other options:

Option B: Vigabatrin irreversibly inhibits GABA transaminase, which degrades GABA. Thereby, resulting in increased levels of extracellular GABA at its receptor and enhanced inhibitory GABAergic transmission.

It is indicated in refractory focal seizures with impaired awareness and infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis. Vigabatrin is associated with progressive and permanent bilateral visual loss.

Option C: Ethosuximide inhibits the T-type calcium currents in thalamic neurons. It is the first-line agent for the treatment of generalized absence seizures.

Option D: Tiagabine inhibits the GABA transporter GAT-1 and thereby reduces GABA uptake into neurons and glia and prolongs the action of GABA in the synapse. It is also used an adjunct therapy for focal seizures.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was treated for a high-grade soft-tissue sarcoma with radiotherapy. Since he was not responding, he was shifted to chemotherapy. After initiating chemotherapy, he developed erythematous rashes over the areas where radiotherapy was administered earlier. Which of the following drugs is likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Doxorubicin can result in a radiation recall reaction where erythema and desquamation of skin are observed at sites of previous radiation injury. 

Radiation recall syndrome is an acute inflammatory response confined to the areas that are previously irradiated, which can be triggered by the administration of chemotherapeutic agents. Studies show that the common drugs causing this phenomenon are:

  • Doxorubicin
  • Docetaxel and paclitaxel
  • Gemcitabine and capecitabine

Radiation sensitization - This is more common than radiation recall. This is a period of enhanced sensitivity in the days after irradiation when the reaction to systemically administered drugs and the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is <7 days. Such reactions can be considered radiation enhancement or sensitization. 

Radiation recall - This is less common than radiation sensitization. When the time interval between the end of radiation and chemotherapy is >7 days, months, or even years.

The major side effects of doxorubicin are: 

  • Myelosuppression 
  • Cardiomyopathy.

Tafenoquine is used in the radical cure of Plasmodium vivax. Total eradication of plasmodium species which includes clinical curative and hypnozoites phase are called radical cure.

Primaquine and tafenoquine (derivative of primaquine) have very high activity against the latent tissue forms (hypnozoites) of the species. It is primarily used for the chemoprophylaxis and radical cure of P. vivax and P. ovale infections.

questions.text: Your friend is planning a trip to the mountains but is concerned because of her history of severe nausea and vomiting while traveling anywhere. Which of the following drugs would be the least effective in managing her condition?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, ondansetron is the least effective in managing motion sickness.

Ondansetron is a 5 HT3 receptor antagonist. It blocks impulses at the peripheral origin in GIT and does not suppress vomiting caused by motion sickness. It is most commonly indicated for the treatment of postoperative and chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. 

Drugs used in the treatment of motion sickness are:

  • Anticholinergic agents (muscarinic receptor antagonists) such as scopolamine (hyoscine) and dicyclomine.
  • Antihistamines (H1 antagonists) are primarily used for treating motion sickness and postoperative emesis.  

Scopolamine transdermal patches should be given prophylactically as it is less effective once symptoms start. It is applied behind the ear at least 4-12 hours before an anticipated exposure to motion. Dry mouth and sedation are common side effects.

First-generation antihistamines such as promethazine, dimenhydrinate, chlorpheniramine, diphenhydramine, cyclizine, and meclizine are effective in controlling nausea and vomiting in motion sickness. Sedation is a common side effect of these drugs. Second-generation antihistamines like cetirizine and fexofenadine are ineffective in the treatment of motion sickness.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was treated with a diuretic for heart failure. He now presents with complaints of hearing impairment and dizziness. Which diuretic is likely to be associated with these side effects?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of drug-induced hearing loss, and furosemide is likely to be associated with these side effects, causing ototoxicity.

Loop diuretics have the potential to cause damage to the ears, resulting in symptoms such as ringing in the ears (tinnitus), hearing impairment, dizziness, and a feeling of fullness in the ears. The risk of ototoxicity is highest when loop diuretics are administered rapidly through an intravenous route and lowest when taken orally. To prevent ototoxicity, it is important to avoid infusing furosemide at a rate of more than 4 mg/min.

Furosemide is a loop diuretic. It acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, resulting in increased excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride. It is used in cases of acute pulmonary oedema, cerebral oedema, hypertension, and hypercalcemia of malignancy.

Hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia are the important side effects.

Other options:

Option B: Thiazides act on the DCT. They inhibit Na+-Cl− symporter present in the distal convoluted tubule. It is used for the treatment of hypertension and chronic oedema. Their adverse effects are as follows:

  • Hypotension
  • Hyponatremia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypochloremia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Decrease glucose tolerance
  • May increase the lipid levels

Option C: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors like acetazolamide inhibit the reabsorption of bicarbonate ions in the proximal convoluted tubule. Used to treat glaucoma and mountain sickness and to alkalinize urine. Side effects are acidosis, hypokalaemia, fever, rashes, and paresthesia. Bone marrow depression is rare but a serious side effect. It is contraindicated in liver disease.

Option D: Tolvaptan is an orally active nonpeptide selective V2 receptor antagonist. Its main mechanism of action is to enhance the excretion of free water by the kidneys, which helps restore normal sodium levels in the blood. It is a new addition to the treatment options for hyponatremia caused by congestive heart failure, liver cirrhosis, or syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). The most common side effects of this medication include increased thirst and a dry sensation in the mouth. Other possible side effects are fever, gastrointestinal disturbances, and elevated blood sugar levels.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male diabetic patient was diagnosed with congestive cardiac failure. He was started on digoxin. What will be the therapeutic plasma concentration of this drug?
questions.solution:
The therapeutic plasma concentration of digoxin is 0.5-1.4 ng/ml.

Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside with a narrow therapeutic index and is used in the management of heart failure. It inhibits the Na+/K+ ATPase pump in the myocardium leading to increased accumulation of intracellular sodium. Increased intracellular sodium prevents the efflux of calcium ions. This results in increased intracellular calcium which increases the contractility of the muscle.

  • Ophthalmic manifestations - Visual aberration is an early indication of digitalis toxicity. Yellow-green distortion is the most common. Yellow halos around lights (xanthopsia) are seen. Visual acuity is reduced.
  • Gastrointestinal manifestations- Nausea, vomiting, anorexia, diarrhea, abdominal pain.
  • Cardiac manifestations - Palpitations, dyspnea, syncope, hypotension. The most serious side effect of digoxin is arrhythmia. They can present as extreme bradycardia, atrial fibrillation, ventricular extrasystoles, bigeminy, ventricular tachycardia, and fibrillation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient was diagnosed with parkinsonism. She was commenced on combination therapy with co-careldopa. What is the rationale behind this combination therapy?

choices.text: To decrease the plasma half life of levodopa
To inhibit the metabolism of levodopa in brain
To promote the metabolism of levodopa in periphery
To reduce the systemic side effects of levodopa

questions.solution:
The rationale behind the combination therapy of levodopa with a peripheral DOPA decarboxylase inhibitor like carbidopa (co-careldopa) is that inhibition of the metabolism of levodopa (i.e. conversion of levodopa into dopamine) in the peripheral circulation decreases the systemic side effects of levodopa, like vomiting.

Peripheral dopa decarboxylase inhibitors (carbidopa) do not cross the blood-brain barrier. Therefore, they only inhibit the conversion of levodopa into dopamine in the periphery and not in the brain. This leads to the increased plasma half-life of levodopa, and therefore, lower doses of levodopa can be prescribed.

Benefits of combination therapy:

  • This therapy inhibits the metabolism of levodopa in the periphery, leading to increased plasma half-life of levodopa.
  • Combination therapy reduces adverse effects like gastrointestinal side effects, orthostatic hypotension, and cardiac arrhythmias.
  • This therapy allows for increased availability of levodopa in the brain.
  • Fluctuation in motor control, where the patient is alternately well and disabled, occurs on prolonged therapy with levodopa. This type of "on-off" effect is reduced in combination therapy because of sustained dopamine levels in the brain.
  • Pyridoxine enhances the peripheral metabolism of levodopa. Hence, combination therapy with carbidopa nullifies the interaction of pyridoxine with levodopa metabolism.
  •  A higher degree of improvement is seen in combination therapy than in monotherapy with levodopa.

Demerits of combination therapy:

This therapy decreases the concentration of levodopa in the periphery, but increases the concentration of levodopa reaching the brain. Involuntary movements and behavioral adverse effects like confusion, hallucinations, nightmares, and delusions are not reduced after the addition of carbidopa. In fact, they are increased in patients who are taking levodopa with peripheral carboxylase inhibitors. This is because higher levels of dopamine are formed in CNS.

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was initiated on haloperidol therapy. Two days later, he presented to the hospital with a deviation of eyes, inability to open mouth, and torticollis. What is the first-line management of this case?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of deviation of the eyes (oculogyric crisis), inability to open the mouth (trismus), asymmetric position of the head and neck (torticollis) are pointing towards a diagnosis of haloperidol-induced acute dystonia. The first-line treatment for antipsychotic-induced acute dystonia is diphenhydramine.

Acute muscular dystonia:

This is an extrapyramidal symptom (EPS) that occurs due to the antagonism of dopamine D2 receptors.

Acute dystonia is more commonly associated with high potency typical antipsychotics like haloperidol and occurs within 1 to 5 days of initiation of therapy. 

It occurs most commonly among younger patients and is characterized by muscle spasms involving linguo-facial muscles causing torticollis, locked jaw or trismus, grimacing, tongue thrusting, and oculogyric crisis in severe form.

Treatment:

  1. Anticholinergic agents like benztropine or diphenhydramine, by blocking striatal cholinergic receptors, balance the dopaminergic activity and is given as first-line treatment for dystonia. 
  2. Benzodiazepines (diazepam) antagonizes the excitatory dopaminergic neurons by their GABA agonist action and are used in refractory cases or when anticholinergic use is contraindicated.

Other options:

Option B: Propranolol is used for the management of akathisia.

Option C: Dantrolene is used in the management of neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Option D: Lorazepam is used for treating anxiety disorders, alcohol withdrawal, and anesthetic medication.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has chronic hypertension since 10 years. He has tried three different drugs A, B, and C to control his hypertension over the years. The graph below shows the relationship between the log[Dose] and the response of three drugs A, B, and C. Which of the following options is true in regards to the drugs' efficacy?
questions.solution:
In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.

Therefore, Drug C has the least efficacy. Both Drug A and Drug B have the highest efficacy that is the maximum effect produced by the drug. Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug B > Drug C.

Efficacy:

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It reflects the capacity of the drug to activate a receptor and produce the response.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy. Thus, in the above image, the efficacy is Drug A = Drug B > Drug C.

Potency:

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response. 
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The more the curve is on the left in a log dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency. Thus, in the above image, Drug A is more potent. The potency is Drug A >Drug B> Drug C.(option B)
